title: More VCs are becoming impact investors
text:
The most relevant to our market is from the latest Responsible Investments Association Australasia report. Looking at the sharemarket, its research shows responsible investments have outperformed 'traditional’ Australian sharemarket portfolios for over a decade.

The industry has also anecdotally found that startups that are impact-led find it easier to hire and retain talent, find it easier to sell to both businesses and consumers, and are also potentially eligible for other funding mechanisms to assist their growth such as government grants.

Aside from the returns and other company building perks, there are a few other reasons that may be the trigger for an impact-focused shift in venture capital. VCs also have a mandate to attract the best deals to the table. Many incredible startups are founded by millennials who have grown up with a mindset around using their work to impact the world - and they want to work with like-minded investors.

There’s also the funds’ own talent to consider. Much like startups, VCs are in their own talent war for analysts and advisors who can help them spot the best deals. I personally chose to work at Giant Leap because of its focus on impact. I know others in the industry feel the same way.

While this trend is growing, and is really taking root in Australia, it’s not universally the case. Not everyone is chasing impact with their deals.

The clearest opposition to this trend comes in the form of a new US VC firm set up to capitalise by countering the impact movement. Launched last June, Vice Ventures is a $US25 million VC seed fund dedicated to investing in companies built around alcohol, gambling and tobacco – companies that have the potential to destroy people's lives.

The most logical argument here is that the mainstream rise of impact-related investment both in VC and at an institutional level has made room for these funds and contrary deals.

We see this as a fringe trend, and given the attitudes of most Australians, we believe it won’t take root here.

Our advice for founders also noticing is that if you’re passionate about a world issue and are using your business to solve it, don’t feel you have to hide this from your investors.

Not all of them will be interested or care. A shrinking number of them may still see it as a disincentive to invest. But you will be surprised by the support you’ll receive from the VC community here if you have a genuine goal to change the world for the better.

Rachel Yang is the investment manager of the Giant Leap Fund.
